an1.41:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sālisūkaṃ vā yavasūkaṃ vā micchāpaṇihitaṃ hatthena vā pādena vā akkantaṃ hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā bhecchati lohitaṃ vā uppādessatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an1.41:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a spike of rice or barley was pointing the wrong way. If you trod on it with hand or foot, it is impossible for it to break the skin and produce blood.

an1.41:1.3.eng: Because the spike is pointing the wrong way.

an1.41:1.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, so vata bhikkhu micchāpaṇihitena cittena avijjaṃ bhecchati, vijjaṃ uppādessati, nibbānaṃ sacchikarissatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an1.41:1.4.eng: In the same way, it is quite impossible for a mendicant whose mind is pointing the wrong way to break ignorance, produce knowledge, and realize extinguishment.

an1.41:1.6.eng: Because their mind is pointing the wrong way.”

an1.42:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sālisūkaṃ vā yavasūkaṃ vā sammāpaṇihitaṃ hatthena vā pādena vā akkantaṃ hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā bhecchati lohitaṃ vā uppādessatīti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
an1.42:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a spike of rice or barley was pointing the right way. If you trod on it with hand or foot, it’s possible it may break the skin and produce blood.

an1.42:1.3.eng: Because the spike is pointing the right way.

an1.42:1.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, so vata bhikkhu sammāpaṇihitena cittena avijjaṃ bhecchati, vijjaṃ uppādessati, nibbānaṃ sacchikarissatīti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
an1.42:1.4.eng: In the same way, it is quite possible for a mendicant whose mind is pointing the right way to break ignorance, produce knowledge, and realize extinguishment.

an1.42:1.6.eng: Because the mind is pointing the right way.”

an1.43:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ paduṭṭhacittaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
an1.43:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual whose mind is corrupted, I understand:

an1.43:1.2.pli: ‘imamhi ce ayaṃ samaye puggalo kālaṃ kareyya, yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye’.
an1.43:1.2.eng: ‘If this individual were to die right now, they would be cast down to hell.’

an1.43:1.5.pli: Cetopadosahetu pana, bhikkhave, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjantī”ti.
an1.43:1.5.eng: Corruption of mind is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.”

an1.44:1.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaccaṃ puggalaṃ pasannacittaṃ evaṃ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāmi:
an1.44:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when I’ve comprehended the mind of an individual whose mind is pure, I understand:

an1.44:1.2.pli: ‘imamhi ce ayaṃ samaye puggalo kālaṃ kareyya, yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge’.
an1.44:1.2.eng: ‘If this individual were to die right now, they would be raised up to heaven.’

an1.44:1.5.pli: Cetopasādahetu pana, bhikkhave, evam’idhekacce sattā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjantī”ti.
an1.44:1.5.eng: Purity of mind is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

an1.45:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakarahado āvilo luḷito kalalībhūto tattha cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito na passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakaṭhalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiṭṭhantampi.
an1.45:1.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, there was a lake that was cloudy, murky, and muddy. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would not see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.

an1.45:1.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, so vata bhikkhu āvilena cittena attatthaṃ vā ñassati paratthaṃ vā ñassati ubhayatthaṃ vā ñassati uttariṃ vā manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ sacchikarissatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an1.45:1.4.eng: In the same way, that a mendicant whose mind is clouded would know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both; or that they would realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones: this is quite impossible.

an1.46:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo tattha cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakaṭhalampi macchagumbampi carantampi tiṭṭhantampi.
an1.46:1.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.

an1.46:1.4.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, so vata bhikkhu anāvilena cittena attatthaṃ vā ñassati paratthaṃ vā ñassati ubhayatthaṃ vā ñassati uttariṃ vā manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ sacchikarissatīti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
an1.46:1.4.eng: In the same way, that a mendicant whose mind is not clouded would know what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both; or that they would realize any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones: this is quite possible.

an1.47:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici rukkhajātānaṃ phandano tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati yadidaṃ mudutāya ceva kammaññatāya ca.
an1.47:1.1.eng: “Just as, mendicants, the boxwood is said to be the best kind of tree in terms of its pliability and workability,

an1.47:1.2.pli: Evamevaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nāññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi yaṃ evaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ mudu ca hoti kammaññañca yathayidaṃ cittaṃ.
an1.47:1.2.eng: so too, I do not see a single thing that’s as pliable and workable as the mind, when it is developed and cultivated.

an1.47:1.3.pli: Cittaṃ, bhikkhave, bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ mudu ca hoti kammaññañca hotī”ti.
an1.47:1.3.eng: A mind that is developed and cultivated is pliable and workable.”

an1.48:1.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi yaṃ evaṃ lahuparivattaṃ yathayidaṃ cittaṃ.
an1.48:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single thing that’s as quick to change as the mind.

an1.48:1.2.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, upamāpi na sukarā yāva lahuparivattaṃ cittan”ti.
an1.48:1.2.eng: So much so that it’s not easy to give a simile for how quickly the mind changes.”

an1.49:1.2.eng: But it’s corrupted by passing corruptions.”

an1.50:1.2.eng: And it is freed from passing corruptions.”

an1.51:1.2.eng: But it is corrupted by passing corruptions.

an1.51:1.3.eng: An unlearned ordinary person does not truly understand this.

an1.51:1.4.eng: So I say that the unlearned ordinary person has no development of the mind.”

an1.52:1.2.eng: And it is freed from passing corruptions.

an1.52:1.3.eng: A learned noble disciple truly understands this.

an1.52:1.4.eng: So I say that the learned noble disciple has development of the mind.”

an1.55:1.1.eng: “If, mendicants, a mendicant focuses on a mind of love even as long as a finger-snap,

an1.55:1.3.pli: ‘bhikkhu arittajjhāno viharati satthusāsanakaro ovādapatikaro amoghaṃ raṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ bhuñjati’.

an1.56:1.1.pli: “Ye keci, bhikkhave, dhammā akusalā akusalabhāgiyā akusalapakkhikā, sabbe te manopubbaṅgamā.
an1.56:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, intention shapes all phenomena whatsoever that are unskillful, part of the unskillful, on the side of the unskillful.

an1.56:1.2.pli: Mano tesaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, anvadeva akusalā dhammā”ti.
an1.56:1.2.eng: Intention is the first of those phenomena to arise, and unskillful phenomena follow right behind.”

an1.57:1.1.pli: “Ye keci, bhikkhave, dhammā kusalā kusalabhāgiyā kusalapakkhikā, sabbe te manopubbaṅgamā.
an1.57:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, intention shapes all phenomena whatsoever that are skillful, part of the skillful, on the side of the skillful.

an1.57:1.2.pli: Mano tesaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭhamaṃ uppajjati, anvadeva kusalā dhammā”ti.
an1.57:1.2.eng: Intention is the first of those phenomena to arise, and skillful phenomena follow right behind.”

an1.58:1.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi yena anuppannā vā akusalā dhammā uppajjanti uppannā vā kusalā dhammā parihāyanti yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, pamādo.
an1.58:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single thing that gives rise to unskillful qualities, or makes skillful qualities decline like negligence.

an1.58:1.2.pli: Pamattassa, bhikkhave, anuppannā ceva akusalā dhammā uppajjanti uppannā ca kusalā dhammā parihāyantī”ti.
an1.58:1.2.eng: When you’re negligent, unskillful qualities arise and skillful qualities decline.”

an1.59:1.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi yena anuppannā vā kusalā dhammā uppajjanti uppannā vā akusalā dhammā parihāyanti yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, appamādo.
an1.59:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single thing that gives rise to skillful qualities, or makes unskillful qualities decline like diligence.

an1.59:1.2.pli: Appamattassa, bhikkhave, anuppannā ceva kusalā dhammā uppajjanti uppannā ca akusalā dhammā parihāyantī”ti.
an1.59:1.2.eng: When you’re diligent, skillful qualities arise and unskillful qualities decline.”

an1.60:1.1.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi yena anuppannā vā akusalā dhammā uppajjanti uppannā vā kusalā dhammā parihāyanti yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, kosajjaṃ.
an1.60:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I do not see a single thing that gives rise to unskillful qualities, or makes skillful qualities decline like laziness.

an1.60:1.2.pli: Kusītassa, bhikkhave, anuppannā ceva akusalā dhammā uppajjanti uppannā ca kusalā dhammā parihāyantī”ti.
an1.60:1.2.eng: When you’re lazy, unskillful qualities arise and skillful qualities decline.”
